summary: Jon Snow, Season 1 I never met my mother. My father wouldn’t even tell me her name. I don’t know if she’s living or dead. I...
caption:
Jon Snow, Season 1

I never met my mother. My father wouldn’t even tell me her name. I don’t know if she’s living or dead. I don’t know if she’s a noblewoman or a fisherman’s wife or a whore.

summary: Haha, you want a question? Well I got one for ya sister! I posted something addressed to Joanna Lannister this morning, and I...
question: Haha, you want a question? Well I got one for ya sister! I posted something addressed to Joanna Lannister this morning, and I wanted to tag you in it, but I completely forgot cuz I'm a ding dong. But I'd love to hear your opinion on that... unsettling matter.
answer:
Putting it under the cut for speculation & spoilers

Do I think Jon and Dany will die in the end? Yes. 

Maybe not in HBO’s Game of Thrones, where the producers have set up emphasis of Jon being heir or Daenerys being a mother, but even them I’m 60% sure they’ll die on the show. 90% sure for books.

More or less what Joanna said: Jon was brought back for a purpose. Whatever magic or God that brought him back didn’t do it because they want to see a Targaryen restoration or because Jon is “on of the good guys”. 

Read this except from ASOS:

“Death and life. Everywhere, opposites. Everywhere, the war.”

“The war?” asked Davos.

“The war,” she affirmed. “There are two, Onion Knight. Not seven, not one, not a hundred or a thousand. Two! Do you think I crossed half the world to put yet another vain king on yet another empty throne? The war has been waged since time began, and before it is done, all men must choose where they will stand. On one side is R'hllor, the Lord of Light, the Heart of Fire, the God of Flame and Shadow. Against him stands the Great Other whose name may not be spoken, the Lord of Darkness, the Soul of Ice, the God of Night and Terror. Ours is not a choice between Baratheon and Lannister, between Greyjoy and Stark. It is death we choose, or life. Darkness, or light.“ 

Whether he is a prince that was promised, a dragon rider, or simply someone with a diplomatic part to play in rallying Dany to fight for the living, Jon Snow has a part to play in the war for the dawn. 

Daenerys most definitely does. Since that night that she walked into her husband’s burning pyre and the music of dragons filled the air, she signed up herself for the destiny of one of the few people in the world with the power of stopping the others. One of the few people in the world who can unite East and West and North and South to fight a common enemy.

Since the first book, George R.R Martin lets us know that our actions have consequences. Even honorable Ned Stark was beheaded for doing what’s right. Being a hero and doing what’s right it’s painful. It’s not “Azor Ahai” painful, where you can simply kill your beloved wife and that pain should be enough to count as a sacrifice.

A true sacrifice would be heart wrenching. I would be knowing your family and friends all live and you’ll never get to see them thrive and be happy, but you know that now they have the chance to live. It would be knowing that you will never restore your family’s dynasty. It would be dying next to your lover and knowing you’ll never watch your child grow up. Because death is the enemy, and life and humanity and love are worth fighting and dying for.

The dragons are not tools to build empires or rule over manmade borders & Kingdoms. They are miracles to preserve life. The fire that burns against the cold.

Jon is a fire wight, and Daenerys is the bride of fire, daughter of death. This is their destiny, and in this darkness and in this cold is where they find each other, and live long enough to understand what kinda of love they’re protecting. 

I hope it doesn’t upset you. For lovers may die but love remains.

Thanks for the question.

summary: Breaking the Wheel
title: Breaking the Wheel
body:
Right Hand Man

After a few days that Robb and Jon arrived at the camp of their father’s soldiers, General Stark was meeting with the top commanders again. This time, they would have to make crucial decisions, already foreseeing a last great battle that would mark the end of the conflict.

“Father,” Robb said, “I brought with me 5,000 Frey soldiers, my initial plan was to get them into the conquered guarded territories. But I think it’s a better strategy to make them fight for the foot of the Wall. We have tried to contain the enemy but even winning they are advancing rapidly to the Far North. They will reach here, they will try to take our power at all costs and we must be prepared”

“Your defense of 5,000 men is perfect,” Commander Baratheon opined, “we wait and attack!”

“I don’t think it is wise,” said Commander Mormont, “the attacks cost us many soldiers.”

“There’s defense in the other territories,” Jon reminded them, “we’ll gather the best troops here and defend our main territory, the North. Sergeant Giantsbane will bring my men here and we will fight with Colonel Stark’s men.”

“An effective defense is still lacking,” Eddard sighed, “we can’t be totally passive or too hasty.”

“Father,” Robb called him regretfully, “call Daenerys back.”

“

"No Robb, she’s suspended.” Ned was categorical.

“Father, you know you need her,” Robb tried again, “there’s no one better than her to solve this.”

“I know,” General General agreed, due to the gravity of the situation, “send message to bring her back.”

No one dared question the order, not even Robert who was indignant, neither Jon fully worried nor Jorah, fearful of meeting to find her again.

On receiving Robb’s message, Daenerys could not contain her satisfaction. Finally she could make the difference that she wanted so badly. With longing but determination, she said goodbye to her family and went to the Great Wall where her father-in-law was waiting for her.

Jon was the first to come to meet her, giving her a hug that took his wife off the ground.

“You don’t seem to manage to get out of trouble,” he teased Daenerys, even worried.

“Don’t worry, I can get rid of the trouble,” she replied.

Eddard quickly explained to her what the Commanders had discussed.

“That territory is well known to us,” Daenerys began, “we will use this to our advantage. Place soldiers at strategic points never used before. And dig trenches, put watchmen on them. They will be the striking surprise element to enhance the defense.”

“We will do as you have said,” said the General, “please, gentlemen, leave me alone with Mrs. Stark for a moment.”

The Commanders obeyed, another wave of concern hovering above them.

“What I’m going to ask for is dangerous,” Eddard warned, “and it will leave me as worried as Jon and Robb, but I know what I’m doing. I want you to take the lead troop at the foot of the Wall and lead the soldiers.”

“Sir?” Dasenerys gasped at the proposal. “Do you want me to command the troops?”

“For your strategy to work perfectly,” Ned explained, “and before you put yourself in the middle of the battlefield, train with Jon every day until the day of the confrontation.”

“Sir, if you’ll excuse me.” She wanted to accept the offer, but something worried her. “Does Jon know about your idea?”

“I’m sure he distrusts my intentions,” Ned confessed, “my purpose is not to endanger you but to win this War.

"I accept, sir.” She nodded seriously.

Of course Jon was worried about Daenerys fighting, but he didn’t question his father. He obeyed his order and endeavored to have his wife know all that was needed to make it as safe as possible.

During these days of training, Daenerys had a little discomfort, which worried her husband a little more. She thought this was a consequence of the effort she was not used to. Jon wanted to believe it, dismissing the thought that Daenerys was expecting a child right on that moment. He wanted a child but not in the midst of War. If Daenerys was sure she was pregnant, which didn’t even go through her mind, she would tell Jon.

And so they spent anxious days waiting for the last battle.

“I’m sure he distrusts my intentions,” Ned confessed, “my purpose is not to endanger you but to win this War.

"I accept, sir.” She nodded seriously.

Of course Jon was worried about Daenerys fighting, but he didn’t question his father. He obeyed his order and endeavored to have his wife know all that was needed to make it as safe as possible.

During these days of training, Daenerys had a little discomfort, which worried her husband a little more. She thought this was a consequence of the effort she was not used to. Jon wanted to believe it, dismissing the thought that Daenerys was expecting a child right on that moment. He wanted a child but not in the midst of War. If Daenerys was sure she was pregnant, which didn’t even go through her mind, she would tell Jon.

And so they spent anxious days waiting for the last battle.

Right Hand Man

“Father,” Robb said, “I brought with me 5,000 Frey soldiers, my initial plan was to get them into the conquered guarded territories. But I think it’s a better strategy to make them fight for the foot of the Wall. We have tried to contain the enemy but even winning they are advancing rapidly to the Far North. They will reach here, they will try to take our power at all costs and we must be prepared”

“Your defense of 5,000 men is perfect,” Commander Baratheon opined, “we wait and attack!”

“I don’t think it is wise,” said Commander Mormont, “the attacks cost us many soldiers.”

“There’s defense in the other territories,” Jon reminded them, “we’ll gather the best troops here and defend our main territory, the North. Sergeant Giantsbane will bring my men here and we will fight with Colonel Stark’s men.”

“An effective defense is still lacking,” Eddard sighed, “we can’t be totally passive or too hasty.”

“Father,” Robb called him regretfully, “call Daenerys back.”

“

"No Robb, she’s suspended.” Ned was categorical.

“Father, you know you need her,” Robb tried again, “there’s no one better than her to solve this.”

“I know,” General General agreed, due to the gravity of the situation, “send message to bring her back.”

No one dared question the order, not even Robert who was indignant, neither Jon fully worried nor Jorah, fearful of meeting to find her again.

On receiving Robb’s message, Daenerys could not contain her satisfaction. Finally she could make the difference that she wanted so badly. With longing but determination, she said goodbye to her family and went to the Great Wall where her father-in-law was waiting for her.

Jon was the first to come to meet her, giving her a hug that took his wife off the ground.

“You don’t seem to manage to get out of trouble,” he teased Daenerys, even worried.

“Don’t worry, I can get rid of the trouble,” she replied.

Eddard quickly explained to her what the Commanders had discussed.

“That territory is well known to us,” Daenerys began, “we will use this to our advantage. Place soldiers at strategic points never used before. And dig trenches, put watchmen on them. They will be the striking surprise element to enhance the defense.”

“We will do as you have said,” said the General, “please, gentlemen, leave me alone with Mrs. Stark for a moment.”

summary: Hi jon x tyrion 65 pls
question: Hi jon x tyrion 65 pls
answer:
Hope that’s horror enough, I’ve never write something like that but I enjoy too much trying something different 

65. Horror

Tyrion wasn’t used to nightmares. He couldn’t remember the last time he had one. Maybe when he was a child, and he was hunted during the night by his sister’s terrible “jokes” -as if he could really believe that those were just jokes, but still-. He wasn’t even sure that was a nightmare, it didn’t look like one. It looked more like a memory, though it couldn’t be so because it was clear from what people were wearing in that fucking dream that it was from another period, from another century, maybe even from another millennium.

But the darkness was there, present and real, and Tyrion couldn’t ignore it. He was too much a man of science to believe in dreams, but that night was different. Perhaps it was because it was Halloween night, perhaps because it was freezing cold. But those blue eyes, empty and too shining, were still in front of him, on pale, too pale skin. And pitch-black curls.

He tuned in the bed, searching for Jon’s body as if seeing his boyfriend could help him in being sure that it was just a dream, but there was nobody there. And didn’t matter that he was keeping tell himself not being stupid -he knew it wasn’t-, his heart wasn’t stopping to rush.

“Jon,” He called. A moment later, he saw something flash in the dark hallway. How he didn’t scream was something Tyrion couldn’t tell, but he managed not to, while red eyes approached him. He knew those eyes: Ghost.

And if Jon’s dog was there, it meant his owner wasn’t so far. Jon emerged from the bathroom soon after. He was paler than usual, but his eyes were still dark even in the dim moonlight which intruded inside their house from outside.

“Jon, are you fine?” He asked, even if it was clear that he wasn’t.

“I had a very strange nightmare,” He answered and his glance was distant. “Something about the Night King or…”

Tyrion had no idea of what he was going to say. The older man knew he was pale. “Jon… I don’t think it was a nightmare.”

He had no idea how he could be so sure but how many possibilities there were that they dreamt of the same Night King?

blog.title: pro jonerys who likes healthy debates

summary: Ohh Joannalannister what have you done to me?
title: Ohh Joannalannister what have you done to me?
body:
(You’re proposing that Jon and Dany sacrificing themselves to save the world would make sense, and the horrible thing is… from a certain perspective, it kind of does TT)

So I went back to scavenging bits and pieces from AGOT (because apparently all the clues are there for the endgame), trying to see if there were clues in there supporting this theory. P.S. This is meant to be a discussion:

“It is not a matter of gold or horses. This is bloodmagic, lady. Only death may pay for life.”

“Death?” Dany wrapped her arms around herself protectively, rocked back and forth on her heels. “My death?” She told herself she would die for him, if she must. She was the blood of the dragon, she would not be afraid. Her brother Rhaegar had died for the woman he loved.

“No,” Mirri Maz Duur promised. “Not your death, Khaleesi.”

Dany trembled with relief. “Do it.”

Ok. This brings me to the arguments you and others have made @joannalannister about self-sacrifice being the only kind of sacrifice that truly counts (shit). What’s particularly shilling here is that Daenerys was ready to sacrifice herself: was that a red herring? Will she be faced with a similar choice once more? As @turtle-paced previously pointed out, her dragons were likely born because she chose to walk into the fire herself (i.e self-sacrifice). Everything else - Drogo, Rhaego - turned to shit because Dany didn’t “need” to sacrifice herself (according to MMD). 

Wind whispered through the stable, a cold dead breath on his face, but Jon paid it no mind. He strapped his roll to the saddle, his scarred fingers stiff and clumsy. “Ghost,” he called softly, “to me.” And the wolf was there, eyes like embers.

“Jon, please. You must not do this.”

Why… urgh, this reeks of nasty I’m-the-sacrificial-lamb foreshadowing (why, @joannalannister, why?). The “cold dead breath”, the “scarred” (remove one of the R…) finger, Sam’s plea… 

Even now, he did not know if he was doing the honorable thing. The southron had it easier. They had their septons to talk to, someone to tell them the gods’ will and help sort out right from wrong. But the Starks worshiped the old gods, the nameless gods, and if the heart trees heard, they did not speak.

Reminds me of another thing you said. That self-sacrifice must be a choice, freely made, not one imposed on you. Not something you’d be coerced into (whether it be by the gods or else). 

A bank of melting snow lay under the trees, bright in the moonlight, water trickling off to form small shallow pools. Jon squatted and brought his hands together, cupping the runoff between his fingers. 

This part I’m not so sure… the “melting snow” probably represents Jon himself, “melting” (whether it’s an identity matter or something more… literal), and it disagreeably reminds me of Ygritte’s death, in a puddle of old melting snow. Then again… you’ve then got Jon “cupping the runoff” (another hint that the snow refers to himself, since he’s running away from the Night’s Watch in this chapter), meaning… what, exactly? 

(There’s also the “bright in the moonlight” part… does it point to J + D?)

Dawn was still an hour off when Jon glimpsed the towers of Castle Black ahead of them, dark against the pale immensity of the Wall. It did not seem like home this time.

(…)

My place is here … where is yours, boy?“

I have no place, Jon wanted to say, I’m a bastard, I have no rights, no name, no mother, and now not even a father. The words would not come. "I don’t know.”

“I do,” said Lord Commander Mormont. “The cold winds are rising, Snow. Beyond the Wall, the shadows lengthen.

There’s another passage in ASOS that seemingly points to Jon’s true “place” being beyond the Wall - it’s where he belongs, it’s who he is. Ick factor is, “beyond the Wall” sounds like a barely hidden metaphor for “dying”. Or… as my dear @joannalannister pointed out, it could stand for the “Faerie” land, the land beyond the curtain of light… 

(It’s bizarre, actually, because I made a post a few months ago about Jon’s death - the first one, anyway, at the end of ADWD - allowing him full “passage” into a more “faerie-ish” self, here. I didn’t really associate this “faerie” land/state/self with death (or death to come), but that’s another matter open for discussion, I suppose :o) 

But anyway, to wrap it up: the Dany passage I cited takes place in the evening (or just before the sunset) and is brought to a conclusion the following morning (or some following morning, doesn’t really matter. That’s accessory.), when she wakes up and find out about the death of her child, Drogo’s vegetative state, etc. The Jon passages I cited takes place during the night and are brought to a conclusion the following morning. So I wonder: are we to take the events of these nights as foreshadowing to what will happen during the real “long night”? Will J and D be “tested” again, faced with difficult choices, and does it more or less spells doom for them, or could it allow for another, less… tragic resolution? 

(I’ll just tag a bunch of people who might be interested in this discussion. You don’t have to respond if you don’t want to though ;-) @nobodysuspectsthebutterfly @instantbouquetface-me @oadara @mysnowdragons @iheartdandelions @tomakeitbeautifultolive @turtle-paced @joannalannister (of couuuuurrse!!) and anyone else who’s want to chip in!

Why… urgh, this reeks of nasty I’m-the-sacrificial-lamb foreshadowing (why, @joannalannister, why?). The “cold dead breath”, the “scarred” (remove one of the R…) finger, Sam’s plea… 

Even now, he did not know if he was doing the honorable thing. The southron had it easier. They had their septons to talk to, someone to tell them the gods’ will and help sort out right from wrong. But the Starks worshiped the old gods, the nameless gods, and if the heart trees heard, they did not speak.

Reminds me of another thing you said. That self-sacrifice must be a choice, freely made, not one imposed on you. Not something you’d be coerced into (whether it be by the gods or else). 

A bank of melting snow lay under the trees, bright in the moonlight, water trickling off to form small shallow pools. Jon squatted and brought his hands together, cupping the runoff between his fingers. 

This part I’m not so sure… the “melting snow” probably represents Jon himself, “melting” (whether it’s an identity matter or something more… literal), and it disagreeably reminds me of Ygritte’s death, in a puddle of old melting snow. Then again… you’ve then got Jon “cupping the runoff” (another hint that the snow refers to himself, since he’s running away from the Night’s Watch in this chapter), meaning… what, exactly? 

(There’s also the “bright in the moonlight” part… does it point to J + D?)

Dawn was still an hour off when Jon glimpsed the towers of Castle Black ahead of them, dark against the pale immensity of the Wall. It did not seem like home this time.

(…)

My place is here … where is yours, boy?“

I have no place, Jon wanted to say, I’m a bastard, I have no rights, no name, no mother, and now not even a father. The words would not come. "I don’t know.”

“I do,” said Lord Commander Mormont. “The cold winds are rising, Snow. Beyond the Wall, the shadows lengthen.

There’s another passage in ASOS that seemingly points to Jon’s true “place” being beyond the Wall - it’s where he belongs, it’s who he is. Ick factor is, “beyond the Wall” sounds like a barely hidden metaphor for “dying”. Or… as my dear @joannalannister pointed out, it could stand for the “Faerie” land, the land beyond the curtain of light… 

(It’s bizarre, actually, because I made a post a few months ago about Jon’s death - the first one, anyway, at the end of ADWD - allowing him full “passage” into a more “faerie-ish” self, here. I didn’t really associate this “faerie” land/state/self with death (or death to come), but that’s another matter open for discussion, I suppose :o) 

But anyway, to wrap it up: the Dany passage I cited takes place in the evening (or just before the sunset) and is brought to a conclusion the following morning (or some following morning, doesn’t really matter. That’s accessory.), when she wakes up and find out about the death of her child, Drogo’s vegetative state, etc. The Jon passages I cited takes place during the night and are brought to a conclusion the following morning. So I wonder: are we to take the events of these nights as foreshadowing to what will happen during the real “long night”? Will J and D be “tested” again, faced with difficult choices, and does it more or less spells doom for them, or could it allow for another, less… tragic resolution? 

(I’ll just tag a bunch of people who might be interested in this discussion. You don’t have to respond if you don’t want to though ;-) @nobodysuspectsthebutterfly @instantbouquetface-me @oadara @mysnowdragons @iheartdandelions @tomakeitbeautifultolive @turtle-paced @joannalannister (of couuuuurrse!!) and anyone else who’s want to chip in!

summary: I love Sansa... because opposite to Bran and Arya, after all that happened to her and her family she didn't become dark, her...
body: I love Sansa… because opposite to Bran and Arya, after all that happened to her and her family she didn’t become dark, her change is good. That is why she became closer to Jon, they both have that in common, they became more caring, mature and responsible, they care for their home and all the people in the North, and they are still soft in their hearts.That’s amazing character development.

summary: Things that need some major explaining
title: Things that need some major explaining
body:
Jon pointedly looking down at his and Sansa’s hands and taking a deep breath.

The look Littlefinger gave after the crypt scene. 

     - My best guess is that he saw he was in the love triangle of Ned and Cat 2.0

LF asking Sansa, “What do you want that you cannot have?” and Sansa never answering. Obviously LF knows that there is something that isn’t making Sansa happy. What could it be?

LF saying “everything you’ve seen before will happen again” or something along those lines….I think they’re also about the Mad King that we’ll see.
